metadata.title: UK Democracy - Complete Collection
metadata.description: Comprehensive quiz covering all levels from basic to expert knowledge of UK democracy
metadata.subject: UK Democracy - All Levels

questions.question: What does 'democracy' mean?
choices: Rule by the richest people
Rule by the people
Rule by the military
Rule by computers
questions.explanation: Democracy comes from Greek words meaning 'people power'. In a democracy, the people choose their government by voting.

questions.question: At what age can you currently vote in UK general elections?
questions.explanation: You must be 18 to vote in UK general elections, though the government plans to lower this to 16 in the future.

questions.question: How many parts make up the UK Parliament?
choices: Two - House of Commons and House of Lords
Three - House of Commons, House of Lords, and the Monarch
Four - including the Prime Minister
One - just the House of Commons
questions.explanation: The UK Parliament has three parts: the House of Commons (elected MPs), the House of Lords (appointed members), and the Monarch.

questions.question: What do we call the person who leads the UK government?
choices: The President
The Prime Minister
The King
The Speaker
questions.explanation: The Prime Minister leads the UK government. They are usually the leader of the political party with the most MPs.

questions.question: How many MPs are there in the House of Commons?
questions.explanation: There are 650 MPs in the House of Commons, each representing a different area of the UK called a constituency.

questions.question: What is the voting system used to elect UK MPs called?
choices: Proportional Representation
First Past the Post
Alternative Vote
Single Transferable Vote
questions.explanation: The UK uses First Past the Post. In each constituency, the candidate with the most votes wins and becomes the MP.

questions.question: Which of these is a key feature of democracy?
choices: Only rich people can vote
Elections happen secretly
Everyone eligible can vote freely
The government never changes
questions.explanation: Democracy means everyone who is eligible can vote freely to choose their representatives. Elections should be fair and open to all.

questions.question: What do MPs do in Parliament?
choices: Only listen to government ministers
Make laws, represent constituents, and question the government
Run local schools and hospitals
Only vote on what the Prime Minister wants
questions.explanation: MPs represent their local area, help make new laws, and question the government to make sure it's doing a good job.

questions.question: Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have their own:
choices: Prime Ministers
Kings and Queens
Parliaments or Assemblies with some powers
Completely separate governments
questions.explanation: Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have devolved parliaments or assemblies that make decisions on some issues like health and education in their areas.

questions.question: What must you show when voting at a polling station?
choices: Nothing at all
Photo ID
Just your name
A driving licence only
questions.explanation: Since 2023, you must show photo ID when voting in person at elections in England. This includes passports, driving licences, or other accepted forms of photo ID.

questions.question: The House of Lords members are:
choices: All elected by the people
Mostly appointed for life
All members of the Royal Family
Chosen by lottery
questions.explanation: Most House of Lords members are life peers, appointed by the monarch on advice from the Prime Minister. They are not elected by the public.

questions.question: How often must UK general elections be held?
choices: Every 3 years
Every 4 years
At least every 5 years
Every 6 years
questions.explanation: UK general elections must happen at least every 5 years, but the Prime Minister can call one earlier if needed.

questions.question: What is a constituency?
choices: A type of election
A political party
An area represented by one MP
A government department
questions.explanation: A constituency is a geographical area that elects one MP to represent them in the House of Commons. The UK has 650 constituencies.

questions.question: Who is the current head of state of the UK?
choices: The Prime Minister
King Charles III
The Speaker of the House
The President
questions.explanation: King Charles III is the head of state. The UK is a constitutional monarchy where the monarch is the head of state but the Prime Minister leads the government.

questions.question: What happens if no political party wins a majority in an election?
choices: There is another election immediately
The King chooses the government
Parties may form a coalition
The previous government stays forever
questions.explanation: If no party wins a majority (more than half the seats), parties can work together in a coalition to form a government.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are constitutional institutions in the UK?
choices: The monarchy and the civil service
The armed forces and local newspapers
Trade unions and pressure groups
The European Union and Commonwealth
questions.explanation: The constitutional institutions include the monarchy, Parliament, the Prime Minister, the cabinet, the judiciary, the police, the civil service, and local government.

questions.question: The UK has an 'unwritten' constitution. What does this mean?
choices: There are no laws governing how the country is run
The constitution is not written down in a single document
Only the monarch knows what the constitution says
The constitution changes every year
questions.explanation: Unlike countries like the USA, the UK constitution is not contained in one single document but consists of laws, conventions, and practices that have developed over centuries.

questions.question: The system of government in the UK is:
choices: A federal republic
A parliamentary democracy
A direct democracy
A presidential system
questions.explanation: The UK has a parliamentary democracy where voters elect MPs to Parliament, and the party with the majority of MPs forms the government.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the role of the House of Lords?
choices: It has exactly the same powers as the House of Commons
It can delay but cannot permanently block most legislation
It only deals with criminal court cases
It controls all government spending
questions.explanation: The House of Lords can suggest amendments and delay legislation, but the House of Commons can ultimately overrule it. The Lords cannot permanently block most bills.

questions.question: How are most members of the House of Lords appointed?
choices: They are directly elected by the public
They inherit their positions
They are appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister
They are chosen by other MPs
questions.explanation: Most peers are life peers appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister. Some are also appointed on advice from other party leaders or an independent commission.

questions.question: Devolution has given Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland:
choices: Complete independence from the UK
The power to make laws in certain areas
The right to leave the UK whenever they want
Control over UK foreign policy
questions.explanation: Devolution has transferred certain powers from Westminster to the Scottish Parliament, Welsh Parliament (Senedd), and Northern Ireland Assembly, but the UK Parliament remains sovereign.

questions.question: In the UK electoral system, a by-election occurs when:
choices: The Prime Minister calls a general election
An MP dies or resigns during a Parliament
A new political party is formed
The monarch dissolves Parliament
questions.explanation: A by-election is held in a single constituency when the sitting MP dies, resigns, or is disqualified during the term of Parliament.

questions.question: The Speaker of the House of Commons is:
choices: The leader of the largest political party
A neutral chair who keeps order during debates
The monarch's representative in Parliament
The most senior civil servant
questions.explanation: The Speaker is an MP chosen by other MPs to chair debates neutrally, ensuring parliamentary rules are followed and opposition parties get fair time to speak.

questions.question: Which of these powers is reserved to the UK government and NOT devolved?
choices: Health policy
Education policy
Defence and foreign policy
Local government
questions.explanation: Defence, foreign policy, immigration, and constitutional matters remain reserved to the UK government. Health and education are largely devolved.

questions.question: The monarch's role in the UK political system includes:
choices: Making all government policy decisions
Choosing which party wins elections
Giving royal assent to make bills into law
Controlling Parliament's daily business
questions.explanation: The monarch has important ceremonial roles including giving royal assent to bills, but does not make policy decisions. The monarch acts on the advice of government ministers.

questions.question: Under the UK's constitutional monarchy:
choices: The monarch rules the country directly
The monarch reigns but does not rule
The monarch only appears on special occasions
The monarch controls the armed forces personally
questions.explanation: In the UK's constitutional monarchy, the monarch is head of state but does not rule. Political power is exercised by elected politicians and appointed officials.

questions.question: Which statement about UK general elections is correct?
choices: They must be held every four years exactly
They must be held at least every five years
They can only be held when the monarch agrees
They are held when opinion polls show a change is needed
questions.explanation: UK general elections must be held at least every five years, though the Prime Minister can call one earlier. The next election must be held by 2029.

questions.question: The Cabinet is:
choices: All Members of Parliament from the governing party
Senior government ministers chosen by the Prime Minister
Civil servants who run government departments
Judges who make legal decisions
questions.explanation: The Cabinet consists of senior government ministers, usually Secretaries of State, chosen by the Prime Minister to head major government departments.

questions.question: In a UK general election, voters:
choices: Vote directly for the Prime Minister
Vote for one MP to represent their constituency
Vote for their preferred political party only
Vote for multiple candidates in order of preference
questions.explanation: In the first-past-the-post system, voters choose one candidate to be their MP. The party with the most MPs usually forms the government and their leader becomes Prime Minister.

questions.question: Parliamentary sovereignty in the UK means:
choices: The monarch can overrule any law
Local councils have supreme power
Parliament is the supreme legal authority
The courts can overturn any Act of Parliament
questions.explanation: Parliamentary sovereignty is a key principle meaning Parliament is the supreme legal authority in the UK and can make or unmake any law.

questions.question: What is meant by the 'opposition' in Parliament?
choices: MPs who always disagree with everything
The largest party that is not in government
Protesters outside Parliament
Civil servants who work against the government
questions.explanation: The opposition is the largest party not in government, led by the Leader of the Opposition. They scrutinise government policy and offer alternative proposals.

questions.question: The principle of 'checks and balances' in the UK system means:
choices: The government balances the budget every year
Different parts of government limit each other's power
Elections are held at the same time
All political parties get equal time on TV
questions.explanation: Checks and balances ensure no single part of government has unlimited power. Parliament checks the executive, the Lords checks the Commons, and courts interpret law.

questions.question: A 'hung Parliament' occurs when:
choices: Parliament is dissolved by the monarch
No party has an overall majority of MPs
The Prime Minister loses a vote of confidence
Too many MPs are absent from voting
questions.explanation: A hung Parliament occurs when no single party has more than half the MPs (326 or more). Parties may then form coalitions or minority governments.

questions.question: Which of the following accurately describes the Salisbury Convention?
choices: The House of Lords should not reject legislation promised in the government's election manifesto
The Prime Minister must consult Cabinet before dissolving Parliament
All bills must be read three times in each House
The monarch cannot refuse royal assent to any bill
questions.explanation: The Salisbury Convention is an important constitutional convention that the House of Lords should not oppose bills implementing the governing party's election manifesto commitments.

questions.question: The 'West Lothian Question' refers to:
choices: Whether Scottish MPs can vote on England-only matters at Westminster
The boundary disputes between England and Scotland
The right of Scottish Parliament to override UK law
The method of electing Scottish MPs to Westminster
questions.explanation: The West Lothian Question asks whether it's fair for Scottish MPs to vote on England-only matters when English MPs cannot vote on devolved Scottish matters.

questions.question: Under the current rules, how many hereditary peers can sit in the House of Lords?
choices: None - all hereditary peers were removed
92 hereditary peers
Any number if they are elected
Only those who also hold life peerages
questions.explanation: Since the House of Lords Act 1999, only 92 hereditary peers can remain: 90 elected by their fellow hereditary peers plus the Earl Marshal and Lord Great Chamberlain.

questions.question: The 'payroll vote' in the House of Commons refers to:
choices: MPs voting on their own salaries
Government ministers and parliamentary private secretaries who usually support the government
MPs who are paid by lobby groups
The final vote on the annual budget
questions.explanation: The payroll vote consists of government ministers and parliamentary private secretaries (around 140 MPs) who are expected to support government policy or resign.

questions.question: Which voting system is used for electing the London Assembly?
choices: First Past the Post throughout
Single Transferable Vote
Additional Member System
Alternative Vote Plus
questions.explanation: The London Assembly uses the Additional Member System with 14 constituency members (FPTP) and 11 London-wide members (proportional representation).

questions.question: The Barnett Formula determines:
choices: How constituency boundaries are drawn
How public spending is allocated between UK nations
The number of peers in the House of Lords
When general elections must be held
questions.explanation: The Barnett Formula is used to calculate the annual adjustments to public spending allocated to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland relative to England.

questions.question: Under the Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011 (now repealed), early elections could be triggered by:
choices: A simple majority vote of MPs
Two-thirds of all MPs voting for dissolution
The Prime Minister requesting the monarch
A referendum on early dissolution
questions.explanation: The Act required either a two-thirds majority of all MPs or a successful motion of no confidence followed by 14 days without a new government being formed.

questions.question: The role of the Lord Privy Seal is:
choices: To control access to the Royal Seal
A senior Cabinet position often without specific departmental duties
To oversee the House of Lords
To advise the monarch on constitutional matters
questions.explanation: The Lord Privy Seal is typically a senior Cabinet minister without specific departmental responsibilities, often taking on coordinating roles across government.

questions.question: What is meant by 'collective ministerial responsibility'?
choices: All ministers share responsibility for government policy publicly
Ministers can only be dismissed together
Cabinet decisions must be unanimous
All ministers must come from the same political party
questions.explanation: Collective responsibility means all ministers must publicly support government policy, even if they disagreed in private, or else resign from government.

questions.question: The English Votes for English Laws (EVEL) procedure was designed to:
choices: Prevent Scottish MPs voting on England-only legislation
Create a separate English Parliament
Give English regions more autonomy
Reduce the number of English constituencies
questions.explanation: EVEL (2015-2021) gave English (or English and Welsh) MPs a decisive say over legislation affecting only England, addressing the West Lothian Question partially.

questions.question: A 'money bill' in the UK Parliament is:
choices: Any bill involving government spending
A bill certified by the Speaker as dealing only with taxation or public money
The annual Budget bill only
Any bill that affects the Bank of England
questions.explanation: A money bill must be certified by the Speaker as dealing only with specified financial matters. The House of Lords can only delay it for one month.

questions.question: The 'Sewell Convention' states that:
choices: The UK Parliament will not normally legislate on devolved matters without consent
Scottish law takes precedence over UK law in Scotland
The Scottish Parliament cannot be dissolved without consent
Scottish ministers must attend UK Cabinet meetings
questions.explanation: The Sewell Convention holds that the UK Parliament will not normally legislate on devolved matters without the consent of the relevant devolved legislature.

questions.question: Which principle prevents the courts from questioning proceedings in Parliament?
choices: Parliamentary sovereignty
Parliamentary privilege
Collective responsibility
The separation of powers
questions.explanation: Parliamentary privilege protects freedom of speech in Parliament and prevents courts from questioning what is said or done in parliamentary proceedings.

questions.question: The Constitutional Reform Act 2005 created:
choices: The Scottish Parliament
The Supreme Court and reformed the Lord Chancellor's role
The Barnett Formula
The Fixed-term Parliaments Act
questions.explanation: The Act created the UK Supreme Court, transferred judicial functions from the House of Lords, and reduced the Lord Chancellor's judicial powers to improve separation of powers.

questions.question: A 'statutory instrument' is:
choices: A type of Act of Parliament
Secondary legislation made under powers granted by primary legislation
A legal document signed by the monarch
A court order interpreting the law
questions.explanation: Statutory instruments are secondary legislation allowing ministers to make detailed regulations under powers granted by Acts of Parliament, avoiding the need for new primary legislation.

questions.question: Which of these can dissolve Parliament?
choices: The Speaker of the House of Commons
The monarch (in practice, on advice of the Prime Minister)
The House of Lords
The Supreme Court
questions.explanation: The monarch has the power to dissolve Parliament, but in practice does so on the advice of the Prime Minister.

questions.question: What is the main difference between devolved and reserved powers?
choices: Devolved powers belong to local councils, reserved to national government
Devolved powers are transferred to Scotland/Wales/NI, reserved remain with UK government
Devolved powers can be changed, reserved powers cannot
There is no difference - all powers are the same
questions.explanation: Devolved powers have been transferred to the Scottish Parliament, Welsh Parliament, and Northern Ireland Assembly. Reserved powers remain with the UK government and Parliament.

questions.question: What role does the Electoral Commission play?
choices: It runs all elections in the UK
It oversees elections and regulates political parties and campaign spending
It decides who can vote in elections
It chooses the dates of general elections
questions.explanation: The Electoral Commission is an independent body that oversees elections, regulates political parties, monitors campaign spending, and ensures electoral law is followed.

questions.question: In the UK political system, what is meant by 'Question Time'?
choices: A TV quiz show about politics
When MPs can ask questions of government ministers in Parliament
Time allocated for opposition speeches
The period before voting begins
questions.explanation: Question Time (including Prime Minister's Questions) allows MPs to question government ministers, helping Parliament hold the government accountable.

questions.question: Which of these is an example of a 'constitutional convention'?
choices: The monarch must give royal assent to all bills passed by Parliament
Elections must be held every five years exactly
All Cabinet ministers must be MPs
The House of Lords has exactly 800 members
questions.explanation: Royal assent to bills is a constitutional convention - an unwritten rule followed by tradition. The monarch could theoretically refuse but never does in practice.
